document.masterDocTitle: Solving an old dilemma: are the two sympatric species Lema apicalis and L. reticulosa (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae, Criocerinae) morphotypes of a single species?

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Solving an old dilemma: are the two sympatric species Lema apicalis and L. reticulosa (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae, Criocerinae) morphotypes of a single species?

Lema ( Quasilema ) apicalis Lacordaire, 1845
,
apicalis
pattern: habitus; 1, dorsal view, 2, lateral view;
reticulosa
pattern: 3, dorsal view, 4, lateral view; intermediate pattern: 5, dorsal view; intermediate pattern: 6, detail of the scutellum, 7, epipleuron, lateral view;
apicalis
pattern: 8, head, frontal view; 9, antenna; 10, labrum; mandible: 11, inner view; 12, outer view; 13, maxilla; 14, labium, ventral view (a7, antennomere VII). Scale bars: 1–5 = 1 mm; 6–9 = 0.5 mm, 10–14 = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Male . Abdomen . Ventrite I subequal in length to II + III; apical margin of ventrite V rounded. Tergite VIII slightly bilobed at apex.

apicalis

Lema ( Quasilema ) apicalis Lacordaire, 1845
: male, 22, tergite VIII, and genitalia; aedeagus : 23, ventral view, 24, lateral view; female: 25, ventrite VII and genitalia; 26, tergite VIII, and genitalia; 27, sternite VIII; 28, vaginal palpi; 29-31, spermatheca:
apicalis

Scale bars: Figs 22–26 = 0.5 mm; Figs 27, 28 = 0.2 mm; Figs 29–32 = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution .
Lema apicalis
is known from southern Brazil , Paraguay , Argentina , and Uruguay ( Blackwelder, 1946 ; Guérin, 1953 ,
Medeiros et al ., 1996
) ( Fig. 33 ). Lacordaire (1845) notes
L . apicalis
in the “surroundings of” Rio de Janeiro (southeast Brazil ) ( Fig. 33 ). Blackwelder (1946) mentions the
reticulosa
pattern in Mexico , which is almost certainly a mistake, as pointed out by White (1987) . This record was based on confusion of the Rio Grande River in Mexico with the Rio Grande do Sul in Brazil .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 33.
Lema ( Quasilema ) apicalis Lacordaire, 1845
distribution map. Circles represent the material examined and squares, data from literature.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Biology . Eggs, larvae, and adults were most abundant during spring (23 September–21 December), in association with their host plant ( Fig. 34 ). In early September, adults started to emerge, with larger host plants carrying more beetles, and by October, specimens were dense on all host plants. During the following months the population slowly decreased, until autumn (May), when beetles were absent at the field site. However, specimens have been collected in autumn and winter months at other sites (see Material Examined). The
apicalis
pattern was much more common than the
reticulosa
pattern, and the intermediate pattern was rarely found.

The only observed hostplant in this study was
Vassobia breviflora (Sendtn.) Hunz
( Solanaceae ) ( Figs 35, 36 ), with distribution in Brazil ( São Paulo to Rio Grande do Sul ), Bolivia , Paraguay , Argentina and Uruguay ( Hunziker, 1984 ). According to Bertls (1962), specimens identified as
L . reticulosa
also fed on
Cestrum parqui L’Herit
( Solanaceae ), but this may be a mistake: the host plant or beetle could have been misidentified, especially because the
reticulosa
pattern is found in other
Lema species.
Vassobia
consists of two species in the small subtribe Iochrominae of tribe
Physaleae (
Olmstead et al . 2008
)
. Adults and larvae feed on the entire leaf, except the large central vein, often defoliating the entire plant, which makes it easy to find the beetles. Copulations both ex situ and in situ were often observed ( Figs 37–41 ). All four possible pairings of the two major colour forms occurred: male and female
apicalis
pattern ( Fig. 37 ), male and female
reticulosa
pattern ( Fig. 38 ), male
reticulosa
pattern + female
apicalis
pattern ( Fig. 39 ), and male
apicalis
pattern + female
reticulosa
pattern ( Fig. 40 ). In the field, males and females copulated with more than one individual, regardless of the color pattern and without obvious preference. All the following observations related to copulation were noted for all four pairs above.

Males often competed to mate with females, even in dense populations. Single males used their mandibles to pull the antennae of the mating male off the female. The behavior was often so aggressive that the copulating male stayed connected to the female only by the terminalia. During these attempts, there was audible stridulation but it was not possible to determine which individual was stridulating.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 34–42 . 34,

on the host plant;
Vassobia breviflora (Sendtn.) Hunz.
: 35, adult plant, fully mature; 36, flower; 37–40,

, copule; 37, male and female
apicalis
pattern; 38, male and female
reticulosa
pattern; 39, male
reticulosa
pattern and female
apicalis
pattern; 40, male
apicalis
pattern and female
reticulosa
pattern; 41, mate guarding; 42, defense behavior (regurgitation).

FIGURES 43–53 .
Lema ( Quasilema ) apicalis Lacordaire, 1845: 43
, development of immature stages on
Vassobia breviflora (Sendtn.) Hunz
(leaf with underside facing up); eggs: 44, one day; 45, five days, immediately pre-hatching; 46, larvae hatching from eggs; 47–50, larval feeding; 51, larvae, last instar, before defecating; 52, larval last instar, defecation and migration to soil; 53, pupae. Arrow indicates regurgitation.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Predatory bugs of the genus
Podisus Herrich-Schaeffer, 1851
( Pentatomidae : Asopinae ) were frequently observed feeding on larvae of
L. apicalis
and this pentatomid was commonly seen on the host plant. An unidentified eulophid wasp was frequently observed parasitising egg masses.
